items.title: 120 Stolen Beehives Recovered in Swift Multi-Agency Operation; Sacramento Man Arrested
items.description: WOODLAND, Calif. — On February 10, 2026, deputies from the Yolo County Sheriff‚Äôs Office, in collaboration with the California Rural Crime Prevention Task Force (CRCPF), arrested 47-year-old Leonid Terzi of Sacramento in connection with the theft of 172 beehives reported stolen from Merced County on February 6, 2026. Terzi faces multiple felony charges, including grand […] The post 120 Stolen Beehives Recovered in Swift Multi-Agency Operation; Sacramento Man Arrested appeared first on
items.summary:
The 120 recovered hives were valued at $450 each, representing a total loss of $77,400 for the owner, Teresa Breshears from Washington state.

The hives were illegally placed on private property in Yolo County. CSBA (California State Beekeepers Association) Vice President Trevor Tauzer alerted authorities after spotting the suspicious colonies, leading to the arrest within 4 hours and the return of the hives to the owner within 12 hours.

CSBA President Ryan Burris and Yolo County Sheriff's Sgt. Matt Wirick praised the collaboration between beekeepers, agricultural organizations, and law enforcement in recovering the stolen hives. Burris noted this was a "rare and welcome success" in the ongoing fight against agricultural theft.

The incident highlights the critical importance of reporting hive thefts immediately to law enforcement and the CSBA. The CSBA offers a reward and investigative support to members whose hives are stolen. Prosecutors also take these crimes seriously, as they harm the farming industry and impact food production.

items.title: It‚Äôs February: Are You Thinking About Tomatoes -- Yet?
items.description: MANHATTAN, Kan ‚Äì It‚Äôs still nearly three months before Kansas gardeners begin to put tomato plants into the ground, yet Kansas State University horticulture expert Matt McKernan says it‚Äôs not too early for gardeners to set themselves up for a bountiful season. McKernan notes that February is a good time to make important decisions on […] The post It‚Äôs February: Are You Thinking About Tomatoes -- Yet? appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
February is a good time to decide on seeds, as the choice can impact the success and duration of the tomato harvest. 

McKernan notes that most home garden tomatoes are indeterminate varieties, which continue growing and producing fruit throughout the season. Determinate tomatoes are more compact and have a shorter fruiting period. He suggests planting a mix of both types if possible, to get a large harvest for canning as well as a steady supply of fresh tomatoes.

Tomatoes in Kansas are typically planted in early to mid-May, when daytime temperatures are above 70¬∞F and the risk of frost has passed. However, in some areas planting may need to be delayed until mid-to-late May. Hot, dry Kansas summers can also cause a mid-season lull in tomato production, as the plants struggle to set fruit when temperatures exceed 95¬∞F during the day and 75¬∞F at night.

McKernan recommends that gardeners choose tomato varieties with strong disease resistance characteristics. K-State's Horticulture Newsletter provides weekly tips for home gardeners, who can also reach out to their local extension office with questions.

items.title: Grape Management Course Blends Instruction and Hands-on Learning for Producers
items.description: STILLWATER, Okla. ‚Äì As Oklahomans continue to explore the grape-growing landscape, Oklahoma State University‚ÄôsDepartment of Horticulture and Landscape Architecture will help spread knowledge with its 2026 Grape Management course. The course, starting March 5 with monthly classes held through September, is open to the public and geared toward growers of all experience levels. Classes will take place from 1 […] The post Grape Management Course Blends Instruction and Hands-on Learning for Pro
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- The 2026 Grape Management course is open for registration at Oklahoma State University, geared towards grape growers of all experience levels.

- The course runs from March to September, with monthly classes from 1-5 pm at the Cimarron Valley Research Station in Perkins, Oklahoma. 

- Registration is $250 per person and closes on March 2. The course is limited to 25 registrants.

- The course covers various aspects of grape growing, including pruning, weed/disease management, irrigation, veraison, harvest, and more. It blends lectures and hands-on learning in the vineyard.

- Specialists from OSU Extension will lead the discussions and provide research-based information to attendees.

- This course aims to help Oklahoma grape growers understand the steps required to successfully grow grapes in the state.

items.title: State Health and Agriculture Officials Conclude Avian Flu Response in Weld County
items.description: BROOMFIELD, Colo. — State health, agriculture, and emergency response officials have concluded their coordinated response to the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) detection at a commercial egg layer operation in Weld County. The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, Colorado Department of Agriculture, State Emergency Operation Center, and Weld County responded together to support the farm and responders […] The post State Health and Agriculture Officials Conclu
items.summary:
Summary:

The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE), Colorado Department of Agriculture, State Emergency Operation Center, and Weld County have concluded their coordinated response to a highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) detection at a commercial egg layer operation in Weld County. 

No human cases were detected, and the emergency response has been demobilized. As part of precautionary monitoring, CDPHE tested 4 workers who reported mild symptoms, and all test results were negative. There have been no confirmed human cases of avian flu in Colorado since 2024.

CDPHE's Disaster Behavioral Health team engaged over 100 responders, workers, and farm leaders, providing psychological first aid and mental health resources to help manage the stress of the response. The Colorado Department of Agriculture, along with state, local, and federal partners, completed the depopulation and disposal activities at the facility on February 6, 2026.

Officials emphasize that it is safe to eat properly handled and cooked poultry products, and anyone who works with poultry or dairy cattle and develops flu-like symptoms should seek medical care or call CDPHE.

items.title: Commissioner Miller Takes Emergency Action to Protect Texas Agriculture From Invasive Leafhopper Pest
items.description: AUSTIN, Texas ‚Äì Texas Ag Commissioner Sid Miller has issued an emergency quarantine on the two-spotted cotton leafhopper (aka cotton jassid, Amrasca biguttula) to safeguard cotton, nursery, and ornamental sectors. After last year’s order lapsed, TDA deemed more time essential to assess pest management tactics and block spread before spring planting. “This pest is a […] The post Commissioner Miller Takes Emergency Action to Protect Texas Agriculture From Invasive Leafhopper Pest
items.summary:
5 billion+ cotton industry, as well as nurseries, ornamentals, and gardens. This rapid-breeding pest can cause "hopperburn", curling leaves, killing tissue, stripping foliage, stunting plants, and slashing cotton yields by up to 50%. 

The quarantine, effective immediately as of February 5, 2026, covers Cameron, Grimes, Fort Bend, and Wharton counties where the pest has been detected. It bans the artificial movement of all live host crops and nursery plants that could carry the leafhopper. Violators face fines up to $4,000, seizure/destruction of items at their cost, and possible criminal charges.

The quarantine will remain in effect until the Texas Department of Agriculture (TDA) completes its post-pest evaluation and revises its assessment. TDA deemed more time essential to assess pest management tactics and block spread before spring planting. Texas A&M AgriLife Extension offers guidance on spotting and battling the cotton jassid.

The leafhopper is a major threat, as Texas cotton alone is a $1.5 billion+ annual industry. The pest also menaces nurseries, ornamentals, and gardens. Without the quarantine, infestations could explode, hiking treatment and compliance costs for farmers, ranchers, and growers.

items.title: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture
items.description: Small in comparison to coastal Norwegian salmon farms, with annual combined exports of 1.2 million tons, Blue Ocean Mariculture produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens submerged 30 to 130 feet under water. Roughly half the fish is sold to distributors and stores in Hawaii, while the rest goes to markets on […] The post Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Blue Ocean Mariculture, a Hawaii-based offshore aquaculture company, produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually, with half sold in Hawaii and the rest to other markets.
- This is small compared to Norway's coastal salmon farms, which have annual exports of 1.2 million tons.
- The bipartisan "Advancing the Quality and Understanding of American Aquaculture Act" (AQUAA Act) seeks to establish a federal regulatory framework for offshore aquaculture.
- The bill is sponsored by Senators Roger Wicker (R-MS) and Brian Schatz (D-HI).
- The goal is to streamline the permitting process and provide more regulatory certainty for offshore aquaculture operations.
- Proponents argue this will help the U.S. reduce its seafood trade deficit and increase domestic seafood production.
- Critics are concerned about potential environmental impacts and impacts on wild fisheries.
- The bill aims to balance economic and environmental interests around offshore aquaculture development.

items.title: NCBA Praises U.S.‚ÄìTaiwan Trade Deal Expanding Duty‚ÄëFree Access for American Beef
items.description: WASHINGTON (February 12, 2026) ‚Äì Today, the National Cattlemen’s Beef Association (NCBA) welcomed the announcement that U.S. beef exports will gain duty-free access to Taiwan under a new trade agreement. The agreement removes both tariff and...
items.summary:
Key points:

- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) welcomed a new U.S.-Taiwan trade agreement that will expand duty-free access for American beef exports to Taiwan.

- The agreement removes both tariff and non-tariff barriers, strengthening one of the most important and fastest growing markets for U.S. beef.

- Taiwan is currently the 6th largest export market for U.S. beef, valued at $709 million in 2024.

- The trade deal eliminates tariffs on U.S. beef and breaks down non-tariff barriers by reinforcing science-based standards consistent with global animal health and food safety organizations.

- NCBA President Gene Copenhaver stated that this will improve competitiveness and provide long-term certainty for U.S. cattle producers who depend on export markets. Beef exports accounted for over $415 per fed cattle processed in 2024.

- The NCBA praised the work of former President Trump and U.S. Trade Representative Ambassador Jamieson Greer in securing this landmark trade deal.

items.title: Who will do the work? Large dairies struggle to secure labor
items.description: For decades, milking families have quietly wondered around kitchen tables and grandstanding politicians have obnoxiously made excuses for their actions and votes, each focused on the same topic: labor. The Montana Stockgrowers Association hosted an...
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Large dairies in the U.S., particularly in South Dakota, are struggling to secure adequate labor for their operations.

2. Drumgoon Dairy, a 6,500-head dairy operation in Eastern South Dakota, lost over half of its workforce when the U.S. Department of Homeland Security deported its Hispanic workers about 9 months ago. This left the remaining 12 employees working around the clock.

3. South Dakota has actively courted large-scale dairy operations through tax incentives, streamlined permitting, and financial aid for infrastructure. For example, the state granted Warner-based Silverstreak Dairies up to $12 million in November 2025 to develop manure containment systems as they plan to double their herd to 5,400 cows.

4. The labor shortage issue is exacerbated by the fact that Americans are typically unwilling to take on these demanding dairy jobs, according to Rick Naerebout of the Idaho Dairymen's Association.

5. Andy Larson, a dairy farmer in Beresford, South Dakota, argues that the labor shortage is not due to a lack of willingness, but rather low pay. He says the 1980s farm crisis led many farm families to discourage the next generation from returning to farming.

6. Small dairy farms in South Dakota are struggling with low milk prices and limited access to processing facilities, making it difficult for them to "make it work" in the current market.

7. The article highlights the urgent need for immigration reform to address the labor shortage in the dairy industry, as well as the challenges faced by both large and small dairy operations in the state.

items.title: USDA to Open Continuous and General Conservation Reserve Program Enrollment for 2026
items.description: Washington, D.C., February 10, 2026 ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) today announced the enrollment periods for agricultural producers and landowners to submit offers for the Continuous and General Conservation Reserve Program (CRP). USDA’s...
items.summary:
The Continuous CRP enrollment period will run from February 12 to March 20, 2026, while the General CRP enrollment will be from March 9 to April 17, 2026. CRP is USDA's flagship conservation program that provides financial and technical support to farmers and landowners to convert unproductive cropland to beneficial vegetation to improve water quality, prevent soil erosion, and support wildlife.

The program currently has around 27 million acres enrolled, with 1.9 million acres available for new enrollments this fiscal year. USDA expects the enrollment to be competitive. Continuous CRP offers will be accepted on a first-come, first-served basis, with a focus on water quality practices like filter strips and grass waterways, as well as restoration of native ecosystems. 

Continuous CRP participants receive annual rental payments and cost-share assistance to establish long-term, resource-conserving vegetative cover. Enrollment options include the Clean Lakes, Estuaries and Rivers (CLEAR) Initiative, CLEAR30 for 30-year contracts, and the Highly Erodible Land Initiative (HELI).

The USDA's Under Secretary for Farm Production and Conservation, Richard Fordyce, emphasized that the focus is on enrolling the acres that can deliver the greatest benefits to soil, water, and wildlife, rather than just maximizing the total enrolled acreage.

items.title: MSGA Accepting Applications for 2026 Summer Internship
items.description: HELENA, Mont. (February 11, 2026) ‚Äì ‚Äã‚Äã The Montana Stockgrowers Association (MSGA) is encouraging college students to submit applications for the 2026 Summer Internship Program. . The deadline to apply is March 1 and the internship duration will be...
items.summary:
The Montana Stockgrowers Association (MSGA) is accepting applications for its 2026 Summer Internship Program. The internship duration will be from May through August, and the deadline to apply is March 1, 2026.

The MSGA Summer Internship Program provides college students with hands-on experience in various aspects of the association, including event planning and execution, policy development, social media engagement, and member engagement. The program is supported by the Montana Stockgrowers Foundation.

Successful applicants must:
- Have at least a 2.5 GPA
- Be an undergraduate college student at the sophomore or junior level
- Have an agricultural, communications, or marketing degree program or background (preferred but not required)
- Possess excellent communication skills and a strong work ethic
- Be U.S. residents
- Be available to work in the MSGA Helena office during the internship duration

The selected candidate will assist the Director of Marketing and Communications with the association's formal communications, including public relations, external communications, member communications, and event management.

"MSGA's Summer Internship is a chance for college students to build meaningful industry connections and develop the leadership skills needed to shape the future of agriculture," said Raylee Honeycutt, MSGA Executive Vice President. "We encourage students who are passionate about the beef industry to apply and be part of the work that supports Montana ranch families."

For more information about the internship program or to apply, visit the MSGA website at http://www.mtbeef.org.

items.title: 2026 Emerging Leader Award Recipients
items.description: The American Quarter Horse Association proudly announces the 10 recipients of the 2026 AQHA Emerging Leader Award: A.J. Kendrick of College Station, Texas Alexis Canen of Circle, Montana Jenna Seal of Stephenville, Texas Kelly Thompson...
items.summary:
The award recognizes outstanding young adult AQHA members aged 21-35 for their leadership abilities and contributions to the equine industry.

The 2026 recipients are: A.J. Kendrick, Alexis Canen, Jenna Seal, Kelly Thompson, Macie Soderquist, Maggie Murphy, Micah Barnes, Nicholas Joyner, Rachel Cogle, and Rafael Martinez. They come from various locations across the U.S. including Texas, Montana, Louisiana, Ohio, Colorado, Iowa, and South Carolina.

The award acknowledges success in the recipients' early careers as well as their service and impact in areas like leadership, science, education, innovation, and ambassadorship. The honorees will be formally recognized at the 2026 AQHA Convention in Las Vegas from March 13-16.

Farnam, a leading manufacturer of equine products, is the sponsor of the Emerging Leader Award. The company has been providing animal health products since 1946 and is one of the largest makers of equine products in the country.

This award highlights the next generation of leaders in the quarter horse and broader equine industries, providing recognition and support for their continued contributions.

items.title: Taiwan trade deal opens markets for U.S. livestock
items.description: Taiwan will provide preferential access for U.S. wheat, beef, pork and dairy products and will start allowing bison meat.
items.summary:
Taiwan has agreed to provide preferential access for U.S. agricultural products, including wheat, beef, pork, dairy, and bison meat. Key details:

- The deal allows duty-free tariff-rate quotas for 8,000 metric tons of U.S. beef and 10,000 metric tons of U.S. pork per year. 
- Taiwan will also fully eliminate tariffs on U.S. wheat and significantly increase access for U.S. dairy products.
- The agreement was announced on November 23, 2022 by the U.S. Trade Representative and Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs.
- The changes are expected to boost U.S. agricultural exports to Taiwan, which were valued at $3.4 billion in 2021.
- Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack stated the deal "will allow American farmers and ranchers to better compete in the Taiwanese market."
- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association and National Pork Producers Council welcomed the agreement, saying it will benefit U.S. livestock producers.

items.title: Not the same old crap: The high-tech future of manure management
items.description: From GPS to variable-rate tech, discover how manure is becoming a precision-driven nutrient powerhouse. Join Ashland SWCD for a deep dive into modern application. The post Not the same old crap: The high-tech future of manure management appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Upcoming "Conservation Chat" event on February 17, 2026 at 6 PM in Greenwich, Ohio organized by Ashland Soil and Water Conservation District.

- Event focused on advancements in manure management technology, including GPS, digital scales, variable-rate application, and precision controls.

- Speakers include:
  - Glen Arnold, Ohio State University - Research on using liquid manure for forage crops and impact of equipment/practices
  - Tubeline Manufacturing - New manure spreader technologies like GPS and digital scales
  - Erica Notley, Ohio Department of Agriculture - Manure application regulations, nutrient management plans, winter application guidance

- Goal is to help farmers stay compliant, confident, and avoid trouble with manure management.

- Information on cost-share programs available, including USDA, NRCS, H2Ohio.

- Tickets are $5 per person or free for two if bringing a friend.

- Manure management has evolved from "get it out of the barn and hope for the best" to a precision, data-driven approach - "not the same old crap anymore."

items.description: A board member at Cal-Maine Foods since 2004, Poole served on several of its committees.
items.summary: Jim Poole, a board member at Cal-Maine Foods since 2004, passed away at the age of 71. Poole served on several committees at Cal-Maine Foods, one of the largest egg producers in the United States. Cal-Maine Foods operates facilities in 15 states and is a major supplier of eggs to grocery stores and food service providers across the country. No further details were provided about the cause or circumstances of Poole's death.

items.title: Michigan alliance pushes ‚Äòsmart trade‚Äô as Trump targets Canada, Gordie Howe Bridge
items.description: A new alliance in Michigan is highlighting how trade inconsistencies have been detrimental for farmers. Mark Fisk with the Michigan Smart Trade Alliance says President Trump‚Äôs threats to block the new Gordie Howe International Bridge between Detroit and Windsor add to the instability in trade discussions. ‚ÄúThe on-again, off-again makes it almost impossible to plan,‚Äù […] The post Michigan alliance pushes ‚Äòsmart trade‚Äô as Trump targets Canada, Gordie Howe Bridge appeared first on Brownfield
items.summary: The Michigan Smart Trade Alliance is highlighting the negative impact of trade inconsistencies on farmers. President Trump's threats to block the new Gordie Howe International Bridge between Detroit and Windsor, Ontario add to the instability in trade discussions, according to Mark Fisk of the alliance. The "on-again, off-again" nature of trade policy makes it "almost impossible to plan" for farmers. The alliance is advocating for "smart trade" policies that provide stability and predictability for the agricultural sector.

There‚Äôs nothing concrete, but the trade seems to be expecting some positive news regarding the U.S./China trade relationship in the near future. CONAB increased its already […] The post Soybeans see more support from demand talk, Brazil quality questions appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.

While no concrete developments, the trade expects positive news regarding the U.S.-China trade relationship soon. Brazil's CONAB (National Food Supply Company) increased its soybean production estimate for the 2022/23 season, but concerns remain over crop quality in parts of Brazil.

items.title: FFBT: Ag lender says farmers starting to rely on operating loans to cover expenses
items.description: An ag lender says some farmers are more reliant on operating loans to cover costs as they prepare for the upcoming growing season.  Kent Burton with Indiana-based First Farmers Bank and Trust says working capital is starting to erode. “We are in about the third year of a down cycle and coming to this, folks had plenty of good equity,” […] The post FFBT: Ag lender says farmers starting to rely on operating loans to cover expenses appeared first on B
items.summary:
Kent Burton, an ag lender from Indiana-based First Farmers Bank and Trust, says that working capital is starting to erode after about three years of a down cycle. Farmers had good equity in the past, but that is starting to diminish.

Burton notes that farmers are utilizing operating loans more to finance inputs like seed, fertilizer, and crop protection products. This reflects the financial pressures faced by farmers due to factors like low commodity prices and rising input costs.

The article does not provide specific numbers or statistics. However, it suggests that the increased reliance on operating loans is a concerning trend, as it indicates the erosion of farmers' financial resilience and working capital. 

The article does not mention any deadlines, names of people/organizations beyond the lender quoted, or provide recommendations for farmers. There are also no expert quotes included.

The key impact for farmers highlighted is the depletion of their working capital and increased need to rely on operating loans to cover regular expenses as they prepare for the next growing season. This can make farmers more vulnerable to financial challenges.
